content.title: Kidney Transplant
content.summary: Kidney transplantation is the preferred renal replacement therapy for eligible patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), offering superior survival and quality of life compared to dialysis. Success depends on careful recipient selection, donor matching, surgical technique, and lifelong immunosuppression to prevent rejection.
key_points: Living donor transplants have superior graft survival (95% at 5 years) vs deceased donor (85%)
Triple immunosuppression: calcineurin inhibitor + antimetabolite + corticosteroids
Hyperacute rejection: within minutes (preformed antibodies); prevent with crossmatch
Acute cellular rejection: T-cell mediated, treat with pulse steroids or ATG
Antibody-mediated rejection: DSA + C4d deposition; treat with plasmapheresis + IVIG
BK virus nephropathy: major cause of graft loss; reduce immunosuppression
content.statement: Kidney transplantation represents the optimal treatment for ESRD, requiring meticulous donor-recipient matching, perioperative management, and lifelong immunosuppression with vigilant monitoring for rejection and complications.

explanation.intuition: Think of kidney transplant as adopting a vital organ that needs protection from the immune system. The recipient's body sees the new kidney as foreign and tries to reject it, so we use immunosuppressive medications as 'peacekeepers' to prevent the immune attack while balancing infection and malignancy risks.
explanation.key_insight: The key to transplant success is the balance between adequate immunosuppression to prevent rejection and minimizing immunosuppression to avoid infections and malignancies. Living donors provide better outcomes due to shorter cold ischemia time and optimal timing.
explanation.technical_details: HLA matching at A, B, DR loci determines compatibility. Panel-reactive antibodies (PRA) measure sensitization. Induction therapy (basiliximab or ATG) provides intense early immunosuppression. Maintenance regimens typically include tacrolimus (target 8-10 ng/mL early, 5-8 later), mycophenolate, and prednisone.

definitions_glossary.allograft: Organ transplanted between genetically different individuals of same species
definitions_glossary.HLA_matching: Compatibility testing of human leukocyte antigens between donor and recipient
definitions_glossary.crossmatch: Test detecting preformed recipient antibodies against donor antigens
definitions_glossary.panel_reactive_antibodies: Measure of recipient sensitization to HLA antigens (0-100%)
definitions_glossary.hyperacute_rejection: Immediate graft destruction by preformed antibodies within minutes
definitions_glossary.acute_cellular_rejection: T-cell mediated rejection typically occurring weeks to months post-transplant
definitions_glossary.antibody_mediated_rejection: B-cell/antibody mediated rejection with C4d deposition
definitions_glossary.donor_specific_antibodies: Recipient antibodies targeting donor HLA antigens
definitions_glossary.cold_ischemia_time: Time organ is preserved outside body; shorter is better
definitions_glossary.delayed_graft_function: Need for dialysis within first week post-transplant
definitions_glossary.BK_virus: Polyomavirus causing nephropathy in immunosuppressed transplant recipients

pathophysiology.mechanism: Surgical implantation of donor kidney with vascular and ureteral anastomoses, requiring immunosuppression to prevent immune-mediated graft destruction

hyperacute.mechanism: Preformed DSA against donor ABO or HLA antigens

chronic.treatment: Optimize immunosuppression, BP and proteinuria control

rejection_treatment.acute_cellular: Methylprednisolone 500mg IV x 3 days; ATG if steroid-resistant

definition.@value: Surgical procedure to implant a donor kidney into a patient with end-stage renal disease, requiring lifelong immunosuppression to prevent rejection

scopeNote.@value: Covers recipient evaluation, donor types, immunosuppression, and rejection surveillance

learning_objectives: Compare outcomes of living vs deceased donor kidney transplants
Describe the immunologic evaluation and crossmatching process
Classify types of rejection by mechanism, timing, and treatment
Design appropriate immunosuppression regimens based on patient risk
Monitor for post-transplant complications including BK nephropathy
clinical_pearls: Living donor transplant: 95% 5-year graft survival vs 85% deceased donor
Negative crossmatch is MANDATORY to prevent hyperacute rejection
Tacrolimus trough targets: 8-10 ng/mL early, 5-8 ng/mL after 6 months
Rising creatinine = biopsy to distinguish rejection from other causes
common_misconceptions: ABO incompatibility is absolute contraindication - desensitization protocols exist
Rejection always causes symptoms - can be subclinical
Immunosuppression doses remain constant - require ongoing adjustment
